title: Wenqing(Cathy) Zhang
text: I’m a first-year ScM student in Biostatistics, passionate about applying quantitative methods to clinical trials, survival analysis, and causal inference. I believe data has the power to directly improve people’s health and quality of life.

title: Wenqing(Cathy) Zhang
text: I’m a first-year ScM student in Biostatistics, passionate about applying quantitative methods to clinical trials, survival analysis, and causal inference. I believe data has the power to directly improve people’s health and quality of life.

title: Wenqing(Cathy) Zhang
text: I’m a first-year ScM student in Biostatistics, passionate about applying quantitative methods to clinical trials, survival analysis, and causal inference. I believe data has the power to directly improve people’s health and quality of life.

title: About
text:
Hi, I’m Cathy! My name sounds like “happy” (开心) in Mandarin, and I like to think it suits me well. I was born in Xi’an, China, and have had the chance to live in several places around the world, including Singapore, Maine, and now Maryland, where I’m currently pursuing my Master’s in Biostatistics.
My academic path weaves together life sciences, social sciences, and quantitative analysis, and I’m especially passionate about research areas like clinical trials, survival analysis, spatial statistics (I love map-making!), and causal inference. I enjoy applying analytical methods to tackle complex public health questions and uncover meaningful insights from data.
Outside of my studies, I’m dedicated to being a globally conscious and environmentally responsible citizen. My experiences living in different countries have shaped my worldview and inspired me to make choices that support sustainability and contribute to a healthier planet. This perspective drives me to make positive changes both locally and globally.

Education

Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health
Baltimore, MD
ScM in Biostatistics
August 2024 - May 2026
Johns Hopkins University
Baltimore, MD
B.S. in Public Health and Environmental Science
August 2020 - May 2024

title: Example Analysis
text:
How do the physical characteristics of different penguin species vary across islands in the Palmer Archipelago, Antarctica?






Intended Audience



This analysis is intended for ecologists, environmental scientists, and conservationists interested in understanding species diversity and adaptations in Antarctic penguin populations.





The data comes from the Palmer Penguins dataset, collected by Dr. Kristen Gorman and the Palmer Station Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) program in Antarctica. (Gorman and Horst, n.d.)
Original Data Source: (“Palmer Station Long Term Ecological Research,” n.d.).










Variable
Description




species
Penguin species (Adelie, Chinstrap, Gentoo)


island
Island in Palmer Archipelago (Biscoe, Dream, Torgersen)


bill_length_mm
Length of penguin bill (mm)


bill_depth_mm
Depth of penguin bill (mm)


flipper_length_mm
Length of penguin flipper (mm)


body_mass_g
Body mass (g)


sex
Sex of the penguin (male, female)


year
Year of observation (2007, 2008, 2009)









Description: The Adelie Penguin is known for its distinctive white ring around the eyes and is one of the most common penguin species in Antarctica.
Source: Australian Museum (Museum 2023)




Description: Named for the narrow black band under its head, the Chinstrap Penguin is often found on rocky Antarctic islands.
Source: Encyclopaedia Britannica (Britannica 2023)




Description: Recognizable by its bright orange bill and white stripe across the head, the Gentoo Penguin is the fastest underwater swimmer of all penguins.
Source: GRID-Arendal (GRID-Arendal 2023)

library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)


Attaching package: 'kableExtra'


The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr':

    group_rows








What Each Package Does




dplyr: Used for data manipulation, providing functions to filter, mutate, and summarize data efficiently.
tidyr: Helps reshape and tidy data, making it easier to organize and analyze in different formats.
ggplot2: Enables creating customizable and professional-quality visualizations for data exploration and presentation.
palmerpenguins: Supplies the penguin dataset, which includes physical measurements of three penguin species.
knitr: Allows for dynamic report generation, making it easy to integrate code and output into a document.
kableExtra: Enhances table formatting in Markdown documents, adding styling options for better presentation.

Each package plays a crucial role in the workflow, from data preparation to visualization and reporting.



# Remove rows with missing values
penguins_clean <- penguins %>%
  drop_na()

# Create a new variable for body mass in kg
penguins_clean <- penguins_clean %>%
  mutate(body_mass_kg = body_mass_g / 1000)

# Group data by species and island, and calculate average measurements
penguins_summary <- penguins_clean %>%
  group_by(species, island) %>%
  summarise(
    avg_bill_length = mean(bill_length_mm),
    avg_bill_depth = mean(bill_depth_mm),
    avg_flipper_length = mean(flipper_length_mm),
    avg_body_mass = mean(body_mass_kg),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Pivot data for visualization
penguins_long <- penguins_clean %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm, flipper_length_mm, body_mass_kg),
    names_to = "measurement",
    values_to = "value"
  )

# Filter data for Gentoo species
gentoo_penguins <- penguins_clean %>%
  filter(species == "Gentoo")



Note: The color palette chosen is designed to be colorblind-friendly, making this visualization accessible to a broader audience.

ggplot(penguins_summary, aes(x = species, y = avg_body_mass, fill = species)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.6) +
  facet_wrap(~ island) +
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma", begin = 0.3, end = 0.8, name = "Species") +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(avg_body_mass, 1)), vjust = -2, size = 3) +
  labs(
    title = "Average Body Mass of Penguin Species by Island",
    subtitle = "Comparison of Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins across Islands",
    x = "Species",
    y = "Average Body Mass (kg)",
    caption = "Data Source: Palmer Penguins dataset"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 15) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14, hjust = 0.5),
    axis.title.x = element_text(size = 14),
    axis.title.y = element_text(size = 14),
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1, size = 12), # Tilt x-axis labels
    legend.position = "top",
    legend.title = element_text(size = 14),
    legend.text = element_text(size = 12),
    plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 1, size = 10)
  )









ggplot(penguins_clean, aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm, color = species)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  labs(
    title = "Bill Length vs. Bill Depth by Species",
    x = "Bill Length (mm)",
    y = "Bill Depth (mm)",
    caption = "Linear trend lines added for each species."
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'










ggplot(penguins_long, aes(x = species, y = value, fill = species)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  facet_wrap(~ measurement, scales = "free_y") +
  labs(
    title = "Distribution of Measurements by Species",
    x = "Species",
    y = "Value",
    caption = "Faceted by measurement type."
  ) +
  theme_minimal()












This analysis revealed that Gentoo penguins generally have a higher body mass compared to Adelie and Chinstrap penguins, especially on Biscoe Island. The relationship between bill length and depth varies among species, indicating different feeding habits and ecological niches. The faceted boxplots showcased the distribution of key measurements, highlighting the physical diversity within and between species.
These findings contribute to our understanding of penguin morphology and can aid in conservation efforts by identifying how different species may respond to environmental changes in the Antarctic ecosystem.



dplyr: drop_na(), mutate(), group_by(), summarise(), filter() tidyr: pivot_longer() ggplot2: geom_col(), geom_point(), geom_smooth(), geom_boxplot(), facet_wrap()

title: Example Analysis
text:
Intended Audience
This analysis is intended for ecologists, environmental scientists, and conservationists interested in understanding species diversity and adaptations in Antarctic penguin populations.

Dataset
The data comes from the Palmer Penguins dataset, collected by Dr. Kristen Gorman and the Palmer Station Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) program in Antarctica. https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/.
Original Data Source: Palmer Station LTER https://pallter.marine.rutgers.edu/.


Data Dictionary
Variable Description species Penguin species (Adelie, Chinstrap, Gentoo) island Island in Palmer Archipelago (Biscoe, Dream, Torgersen) bill_length_mm Length of penguin bill (mm) bill_depth_mm Depth of penguin bill (mm) flipper_length_mm Length of penguin flipper (mm) body_mass_g Body mass (g) sex Sex of the penguin (male, female) year Year of observation (2007, 2008, 2009)
  
https://australian.museum/learn/animals/birds/adelie-penguin/ https://www.britannica.com/animal/chinstrap-penguin https://www.grida.no/resources/3186

library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)


Attaching package: 'kableExtra'


The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr':

    group_rows



# Remove rows with missing values
penguins_clean <- penguins %>%
  drop_na()

# Create a new variable for body mass in kg
penguins_clean <- penguins_clean %>%
  mutate(body_mass_kg = body_mass_g / 1000)

# Group data by species and island, and calculate average measurements
penguins_summary <- penguins_clean %>%
  group_by(species, island) %>%
  summarise(
    avg_bill_length = mean(bill_length_mm),
    avg_bill_depth = mean(bill_depth_mm),
    avg_flipper_length = mean(flipper_length_mm),
    avg_body_mass = mean(body_mass_kg)
  )

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'species'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

# Pivot data for visualization
penguins_long <- penguins_clean %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm, flipper_length_mm, body_mass_kg),
    names_to = "measurement",
    values_to = "value"
  )

# Filter data for Gentoo species
gentoo_penguins <- penguins_clean %>%
  filter(species == "Gentoo")


# Load the viridis package for color palettes
library(viridis)

Loading required package: viridisLite

# Updated plot with a colorblind-friendly palette
ggplot(penguins_summary, aes(x = species, y = avg_body_mass, fill = species)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.6) +
  facet_wrap(~ island) +
  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "plasma", begin = 0.3, end = 0.8, name = "Species") +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(avg_body_mass, 1)), vjust = -1, size = 3) +
  labs(
    title = "Average Body Mass of Penguin Species by Island",
    subtitle = "Comparison of Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins across Islands",
    x = "Species",
    y = "Average Body Mass (kg)",
    caption = "Data Source: Palmer Penguins dataset"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 15)









# Scatter plot with smoothing line
ggplot(penguins_clean, aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm, color = species)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  labs(
    title = "Bill Length vs. Bill Depth by Species",
    x = "Bill Length (mm)",
    y = "Bill Depth (mm)",
    caption = "Linear trend lines added for each species."
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'










# Faceted boxplot
ggplot(penguins_long, aes(x = species, y = value, fill = species)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  facet_wrap(~ measurement, scales = "free_y") +
  labs(
    title = "Distribution of Measurements by Species",
    x = "Species",
    y = "Value",
    caption = "Faceted by measurement type."
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

title: Example Analysis
text:
Summary
This analysis revealed that Gentoo penguins generally have a higher body mass compared to Adelie and Chinstrap penguins, especially on Biscoe Island. The relationship between bill length and depth varies among species, indicating different feeding habits and ecological niches. The faceted boxplots showcased the distribution of key measurements, highlighting the physical diversity within and between species.
These findings contribute to our understanding of penguin morphology and can aid in conservation efforts by identifying how different species may respond to environmental changes in the Antarctic ecosystem.

  mutate(body_mass_kg = body_mass_g / 1000)
